item.title: China Land Sales Income Hits Decade Low, Widening Budget Deficit
item.description: China’s revenue from selling land plunged to the lowest in a decade, contributing to the widening of budget deficit as the government ramped up spending in support of the economy.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

item.title: Pacific Basin Avoiding Arabian Sea on Mideast Crisis
item.description:
Martin Fruergaard, CEO dry bulk ship owner and operator Pacific Basin, says the Hong Kong-listed firms have stopped committing to additional voyages into the Arabian gulf on security concerns, despite having tried to evaluate going through the Red Sea again. He added that industry peers are also doing the same even though just 2 percent of dry cargo volume goes through those waters. He also gives his outlook for freight prices in an interview with Yvonne Man and David Ingles on "Bloomberg: The China Show."
(Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil, Dollar Trim Gains After US Attacks on Iran: Markets Wrap
item.description: The dollar and oil pared an early advance, as traders awaited Tehran’s response after Washington struck Iran’s nuclear sites over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

media:content.media:description: Oil storage containers in Midland, Texas, US, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. Oil steadied following its biggest one-day jump in almost a year as fears that Israel may decide to strike Iranian crude facilities in retaliation for a missile barrage kept the market on edge.

item.title: China Rips Trump’s Iran Attack in First Comment Since US Hit
item.description: China criticized the US strike on Iranian nuclear facilities and reiterated that it’s willing to join international efforts to restore peace in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Yian Lee

item.title: Trump Doesn’t Always Chicken Out
item.description: If there’s a model for hope how, it may lie in how quickly the 1991 Gulf War ended.
item.dc:creator: John Authers

media:content.media:description: An Iranian protester shouts anti-U.S. and anti-Israeli slogans while standing next to the portraits of Iran's Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and late leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, during a protest to condemn the U.S. attacks on Iran's nuclear facilities in downtown Tehran, Iran, on June 22, 2025, amid the Iran-Israel war. (Photo by Morteza Nikoubazl/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: South Korean Bourse Prepares to Launch Carbon-Emissions Futures
item.description: South Korea’s main stock exchange plans to roll out futures on carbon emissions to deepen the market for the sector and help with the nation’s push toward net-zero emissions by 2050.
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty, Youkyung Lee

item.title: Dollar Gains as the World Awaits Iran’s Response to US Attack
item.description: The dollar strengthened on Monday as investors sought to shield against mounting geopolitical risks following the US strikes on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani, Anya Andrianova, Macarena Munoz Montijano, Ruth Carson

item.title: Bloomberg: The Asia Trade 6/23/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Tokyo and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Cobalt Prices and Shares Spike After Congo Extends Ban
item.description: Cobalt prices and shares surged in China after the Democratic Republic of Congo extended its export ban to September, constricting supplies of the raw material used in alloys and batteries.
item.dc:creator: Annie Lee

item.title: Two Supertankers U-Turn in Strait of Hormuz After US Strikes
item.description: Two supertankers, each capable of hauling about 2 million barrels of crude, U-turned in the Strait of Hormuz after US airstrikes on Iran raised the risk of a response that would ensnare commercial shipping in the region.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz. Photographer: Kaveh Kazemi/Getty Images

item.title: Oil Pushes Higher as Market Weighs Risks After US Strikes Iran
item.description: Oil jumped after the US struck Iran’s nuclear sites, stoking concerns that energy supplies from the Middle East could be disrupted.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Smoke from the Shahran oil depot, following a missile strike northwest of Tehran, on June 16. Photographer: ATTA KENARE/AFP

item.title: Gold Edges Lower in Asia Even After Middle East Conflict Worsens
item.description: Gold edged lower, reversing an earlier advance, as the world waited for Iran’s response after the US joined Israel in attacking the Islamic Republic over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Paul-Alain Hunt, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: The escalation of hostilities has given fresh impetus to a rally that’s pushed gold up almost 30% so far this year. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Market Is 'Polarized' Following US Strike on Iran, CBA's Dhar Says
item.description: Vivek Dhar, mining and energy analyst at the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, shares his views on oil prices following the US strike on Iranian nuclear facilities. He speaks on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: HDB IPO’s Deep Discount Offers Reality Check to Indian Investors
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Alex Gabriel Simon

item.title: Japan Activist Clout Shown in Shareholder Rejection of Taiyo CEO
item.description: Shareholders’ rejection of another term for Eiji Sato as Taiyo Holdings Co. chief executive officer over the weekend was a rare event highlighting the growing clout of activists in Japan’s stock market.
item.dc:creator: Koh Yoshida

item.title: UBS Downgrades Thai Stocks to Neutral as Political Woes Weigh
item.description: UBS Group AG strategists downgraded Thai stocks to neutral from overweight, citing recent political uncertainty which could impact policy direction and investor sentiment.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng

item.title: Montage Is Said to Hire Banks for $1 Billion Hong Kong Listing
item.description: Chinese chip designer Montage Technology Co. has hired banks for its planned Hong Kong listing that could raise about $1 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

item.title: China’s Rains Arrive at Critical Moment for Coal and Dam Sectors
item.description: The heavy rains rolling though southwestern and central China are filling up the rivers and reservoirs that feed the country’s mighty dams, posing another threat to the coal market that competes with hydropower in electricity generation.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh, Mary Hui

media:content.media:description: The dam of the Langdong Navigation and Hydropower Hub on the Duliujiang River was opened for flood discharge in Guizhou Province on June 21. Photographer: CFOTO/Future Publishing/Getty Images

item.title: China 'Strongly' Condemns US Strike on Iran's Nuclear Program
item.description: China has criticized the US strike on Iranian nuclear facilities and reiterated that it’s willing to join international efforts to restore peace in the Middle East. Bloomberg's Minmin Low reports on the latest. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: IMF Georgieva on Eco Impact from MidEast Conflict
item.description: Kristalina Georgieva, Managing Director at IMF, says the impact of the Middle East escalation on energy supplies and prices is a key concern and shared her outlook on rising geopolitical risks facing the global economy. She speaks with Shery Ahn on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Goldman Flags Scope for Higher Oil and Gas on Mideast Scenarios
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. flagged the possibility of higher oil and gas prices after the US struck Iran, even as the bank’s base-case outlook hinges on major disruptions to supplies from the region.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: Photo by ISSOUF SANOGO/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ISSOUF SANOGO/AFP

item.title: Rupee’s Fall Near Key Level to Test RBI’s Tolerance for Swings
item.description: The Indian rupee’s decline against the dollar is pushing it closer to a critical threshold, raising expectations that the nation’s central bank may step in to stabilize the currency as global tensions mount.
item.dc:creator: Pratigya Vajpayee, Bhaskar Dutta

item.title: Japan Flags Big Cut to Long-End Bond Issuance Before Auction
item.description: Japan’s larger-than-expected cut to super-long bond issuance has potential to ease some upward pressure on yields just before an auction this week that risks reigniting turmoil in the debt market.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Mount Fuji and the Shinjuku skyline in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Feb. 14, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release its fourth-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Feb. 17.

item.title: IMF Watching Iran Situation 'Very Closely'
item.description: IMF Managing-Director Kristalina Georgieva tells Bloomberg TV that the US strikes on Iran are another source of uncertainty in an already highly uncertain environment. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tesla Starts Long-Awaited Robotaxi Service With Low-Key Rollout
item.description: Tesla Inc. rolled out its long-promised driverless taxi service to a handful of riders Sunday, a modest debut for what Elon Musk sees as a transformative new business line.
item.dc:creator: Kara Carlson

media:content.media:description: A Tesla robotaxi vehicle in Austin on June 22.

item.title: Investors Wooed With Freebies at Japan’s Shareholder Meetings
item.description: More Japanese companies are giving gifts at annual general meetings in a practice that could increase the ranks of loyal retail investors as pressure from activist investors grows.
item.dc:creator: Momoka Yokoyama

item.title: Oil Market Get Fresh Injection of Uncertainty After US Strikes Iran
item.description: US strikes on Iran over the weekend have added to risks for global oil supply, which has so far been unaffected by some of the most extreme military actions in the Middle East in years.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Sarah Chen, Dan Murtaugh, Nicholas Lua

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brandon Bell/Getty Images Photographer: Brandon Bell/Getty Images North America

item.title: Markets React Sharply to US Airstrikes on Iran
item.description: Crude oil futures are surging in early Monday trading, as widely expected, with US equity futures gapping lower after the US launched strikes against Iran over the weekend. Bloomberg's Romaine Bostick reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Employment, Inflation Risks Roughly in Balance
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said she sees the central bank’s monetary policy stance as “in a good place” currently, with risks to its US employment and price stability mandates as roughly equal.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, during the National Association of Business Economics (NABE) economic policy conference in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 16, 2024. The theme of this year's annual meeting is Navigating Geopolitical Turbulence and Domestic Uncertainty. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Mild US Inflation Is Backdrop for Fed’s Powell on the Hill
item.description: US inflation probably inched higher in May, offering scant evidence of extensive tariff-related repercussions that the Federal Reserve expects to become more apparent later in the year.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 18, 2025. Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and continued to pencil in two rate cuts in 2025, saying uncertainty over the economic outlook was still high but had diminished.
